review:
This game is like Papers, Please where you examine documents according to daily rules,. However, this interface-heavy game fail in both UI & UX fronts. The UI elements is buggy and in the way almost every day. Animations are slow, and you wish it would go faster. I don't even know if there's a time limit because no UI explicitly tell you that (maybe they tell you that in the manual, but good UI doesn't need manual). The "Live" information display only show one line, and often hide information. UI elements obscure subjects in corners of the map (like Alaska, Australia). UX is bad because you cannot open multiple suspects at once, while some mission objective ask you to compare information across several suspects. Large part of the UI are unusable space.

There's some story that might be interesting, with eleemnts from real world. But it's full of filler missions that make the game move 10x slower than Papers, Please or Orwell. And even though many games in this genre do have different routes for your decision, this game force you into choices. Characters will add themselves to your contacts even if you refuse (by giving you "an offer you cannot refuse") and threaten you with game over if relationship is not maintained. Some story choice is an illusion that either do nothing or resulting in game over.

author: {'steamid': '76561198845183546', 'num_games_owned': 1631, 'num_reviews': 45, 'playtime_forever': 1575, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1575, 'last_played': 1695766345}
review:
Well, I certainly have some thoughts about this game after beating it. Let’s get through them starting with the positives.

- The soundtrack is great! It adds to the intensity and urgency during some missions and very much fits with the whole mass surveillance theme. 
- Some missions were very good and fun. Definitely some memorable ones especially when you got better clearance levels. (As long as they weren’t crossmatch missions which I’ll get to in a bit) 

And that’s about it with the positives :/ on to the negatives which overall, lead me to not recommend this game especially if you respect your time.

- Bad tutorials. One of the biggest problems with the game. The guide talks pretty fast and the dialogue during its explanations keeps going rather than clicking to proceed which can make you easily miss information on what to do. Often times I felt like I was thrown into a pool expecting to know how to swim. This was especially the case with what I think is the worst mission type in the game, crossmatch. I was just lost with these missions and just rushed through them. I saw in a couple of cases I could just approve everyone very quickly and my performance would still be good.
- Money is useless. All you can do with your hard earned cash is spending it on items for your house that serve no purpose other than just sitting there. [spoiler] (Near the end of the game, you go to prison and are on the run after escaping which further adds to the uselessness of money and items from the shop.)[/spoiler] You never have to pay rent other than one point in the game but you can easily do something to not pay. Other similar games like Not Tonight, papers please etc had much better economies and it would’ve been nice to have some upgrades for work that you could buy.
- The game overstays it’s welcome. I think this game is way too long and drags on especially with the home missions where you have to find data to sell. At first they were alright but it got really tedious once you had to balance between 3 sellers. I didn’t do the home missions for money, more so I did them to keep the relationship between the sellers high and not get a game over. I think what would’ve been better is to have the main story be shorter and make an endless mode for those who want more. 
- Unfulfilled promises. I certainly think this is one of the biggest disappointments. Once I learned this game was made possible by kickstarter, I went to its page and saw that the only stretch goals implemented were a series of missions like taking down a cult, finding stolen artifacts, rigging an election etc. The ones that would’ve been really nice like better customization, clearance level 0 and arcade mode were never implemented despite being reached. I also saw comments from the dev saying they are working on a spin-off for this game but that was back in 2020 and their social media hasn’t had a post since then which leads me to believe they’ve abandoned plans altogether which is a big shame.

review:
Overall I did like playing the game but I feel it could be way better. I backed the game on Kickstarter and finally took the time to play through it.

I mostly liked the game the game mechanics but it was too long for me with about 25-30h to complete. I felt some clearance levels were stretching for way too long and a shorter experience would have been more enjoyable.

The story is completely linear and you only have an illusion of choice with the dialogue. The only variation possible from the story is to lose. I made the choice to not interact with anyone with the dating app but the story forces you to be in couple with your hometown friend. I never leaked data to Denys but it still ends up backfiring at you. Same thing goes with Tripwire, you have no other way to handle them.

During the game, I never felt there was much at stake. I would have liked to have some dilemma when making a decision for suspects. The only times I wasn't 100% in compliance was because I made slight mistakes, never because I was compelled to protect people or serve some personnal interest. So most of the time I had no interest to know how much % of compliance I gained, nor my ranking changed.

The part I most enjoyed was the end where the rythm was different, even if it was still linear, I liked the sense of story progression and the interrogation gameplay.

I would love to see a sequel, maybe shorter with a non linear story and more stakes.

review: This game is ok - but just ok. It has a great concept for those who like political/dystopian/investigative games, like myself. Nonetheless, the game falls rather short considering there really are no choices you can make (technically, there are, but these choices just mean the game is over before its real ending). I value choices in these types of games more than anything, however the developers really had just one type of character in mind; you can't be completely devoted to the Department, and you can't be a rebel either. Also, although day-to-day duties are interesting at first, later they become really boring, except for few meaningful investigations, so the developers could have made the game shorter without sacrificing anything, really. Still recommended for people who like these types of games, just don't expect too much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198274136875', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 1292, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1292, 'last_played': 1676147710}
review:
I do recommend this game but it’s not without its faults and some of those are gameplay problems.  I would give this a 3/5 if such a ratings system existed on Steam.

This game reminds me a lot of Papers, Please but it lacks the urgency of PP.  There is a clock ticking down but as far as I could tell there were no repercussions to letting it run out.  Most of the missions were solved within 2 hours of the clock ticking and there’s no pro or con to finishing by a certain time.  This is one of many parts of the game where I thought, “Why is this here, it serves no purpose”.

The after work missions get extremely tedious.  I did all of them but I wonder if you didn’t whether the ending would have been different.  Something tells me it would not have mattered.  You get money but besides one particular time, it doesn’t matter if you do anything with it or not.  There’s another after work “task” that you can do that does nothing other than add a distraction (trying to be vague to be spoiler free here) and I stopped doing it halfway through the game with again, no repercussions.

Trying to select points on the map is a huge pain especially when there are multiple suspects in a location.  The map keeps scrolling and the location point doesn’t lock very well onto the mouse.  A lot (all maybe?) of the dialogue screens are off-center and near the bottom of the screen.  So you’re watching a cut scene and it’s in the bottom 30% of your computer monitor and not centered. Seems like a weird style choice along with half-hiding the graphics for home/office/etc.  There are a couple of missions that I had to write down data or take pictures of the screen to correlate data between people because there wasn’t a good way of doing this in game.  Also had some graphics issues where the screen would bounce around randomly.

The last act of the game really tried my patience.  I had to restart multiple levels because the data I was pulling wasn’t right and this is already a very lengthy game where there isn’t a meaningful change in mechanics so it was feeling REALLY tedious by this point.

All that having been said, I did enjoy the game from a storyline standpoint and the data correlation/searching aspect.  If there was a sequel with the gameplay problems fixed and the stakes were higher, I would definitely check it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561198033250688', 'num_games_owned': 356, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 1397, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1397, 'last_played': 1654277986}
review:
Backed it on Kickstarter (I'm even in the credits if you looked!), played it, abandoned it for a few years, and then finally finished it, doesn't mean it's a boring game, hear me out.

Need to Know came from the era of Orwell - which I've also played, loved and reviewed - basically pattern matching gameplay laid on top of a "visual" novel (only without boobs). The gameplay, while has to be involved and brain-teasing, needs to tells a story.

Orwell excelled with being a more aggressively ramped-up authoritarian nightmare. A seemingly more far-fetched future. A story where an outsider can help control information, narratives, and through that, the truth and history.

(Mild spoilers ahead, skip next paragraph if you don't wanna know anything)

Need to Know, on the other hand, writes a story in a near future - where we may be right now, or in a few years. You play as a US citizen, whose sole power is to prosecute, to "just follow orders", and meanwhile trying to survive a personal political hell. You play yourself into becoming a regular crimer, a warcrimer, and a national terrorist. You see repercussion of your own actions in the story. You may justify yourself into believing you're fighting for "the truth"; yet the information you are given keeps getting worse, and it makes you wonder if you're becoming a eugenicist and a fascist. At that point, the only winning move may just be not to play, or yeet yourself into prison.

(Spoiler over)

If you choose to play on, the gameplay is more involved than Orwell - while Orwell only makes you marks single pieces of evidence, Need to Know makes you show the link between different pieces of seemingly unrelated information - only becoming related because you are given inside knowledge of what they may have been doing. Messages, tweets, locations, bank statements, satellite images, heartbeats - all the data we give willingly these days - can and will be used against them. You request more data, you use that data to find incriminating evidence, and you string them together to prosecute them. Everyday is like a mini-Sherlock Holmes mind palace minigame, only it keeps getting more complicated. It can get repetitive, but being engaged to the story and the new data types will help mitigate it a little bit.

The game represents a possible future, and you are a judge, jury, and executioner. Have fun doing war crimes.

review:
I do enjoy the game so far but have not ventured too far down the rabbit hole. It does remind me of Papers Please, Orwell and such, which if you are into, this should be right up your alley. This game requires a lot of my concentration, due to spotting tiny differences like spelling mistakes, timing of phone calls instead of just the contact person etc. It's not necessarily a bad thing, but I can't play it for too long as I would feel mentally tired after a while. It's a fun game I pop into for a couple sessions and then hop out of, and not something I can play all night and feel relaxed. 

All in all I would recommend if you enjoy this genre, and I did feel like I was making a difference with my "work", I guess. My main gripe is something lot of other reviews have mentioned, that the game was marketed as a game of choice, so you could choose to use your "powers" for good or evil, choose how you handle the information and what side you are on etc. However, this is not truly the case because you end up having to balance all the different "sides" to avoid a game over. This feels incongruent with the marketing and does not feel too nice when you realize you have to play all the sides, essentially lying to everyone, and cannot really play the game the way you want to, or that your character would have. The storyline is pretty linear so far, which also does not match my expectation of the game and I've been following it's development from way back.

Other than that, it's an interesting take on the surveillance topic. Wish there was an easier mode for when I want to chill out, or a creative mode that does not force me to make a choice I do not want to, is all.

author: {'steamid': '76561197991156884', 'num_games_owned': 1616, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 2382, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1203, 'last_played': 1640304274}
review:
I wanted very much to like this game and was a very early kickstarter backer, however, Monomyth overpromised hard and under-delivered catastrophically. The game isn't anywhere near what was promised (equivalent to the bad state of "No Man's Sky" at release).

None of the stretch goals were ever implemented, despite getting 4x the amount requested and it being a popular game on Steam at one time.

The game promised "meaningful choices", and various other options and customizability, but most "choices" [spoiler]merely lead to a game over[/spoiler].

This game had so much promise, and unfortunately, the game developers weren't and aren't clear about what the game actually entails, and a lot comes down to fussy micromanaging of elements outside of normal gameplay that aren't fun, rewarding, or interesting. Your choices there also don't appear to actually matter.

I fell for the idea of this game immediately when it was pitched, I was super patient, but this game ends up getting a hard pass from me. There's nowhere near enough actual "game" to play, and even with fewer bugs, it's mostly an exercise in frustration.

The sad thing was? I would've been happy to give the developer a lot more credit if they had ever done exactly one thing: been a lot more honest and up-front with what was and wasn't going to happen with the community. The community was never valued by this company, and unfortunately that means unlike the disaster that used to be "No Man's Sky", this is a game that, while at least it wasn't instantly abandoned, will never end up being even half the game that was promised.

Also unfortunately, since the decision to not do any of the stretch goals, and not truly "complete" the game as promised, obviously wasn't sudden...this is the sort of game where it WOULD have been a saving grace if they would've let the community take up the mantle via modding support, but this also never happened.

This is [b]THE[/b] game that made me completely stop participating in KickStarter. Overpaying to get less™️.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971269084', 'num_games_owned': 659, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 1768, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1768, 'last_played': 1636925221}
review:
Image you have a good core gameplay idea. From there you have two ways to make a game out of it.
Number 1 is trying to expand that gameplay idea with many additions and variations.
Number 2 is an nearly endless loop of the same basic idea with nothing more then graphical changes (aka the way most mobile games work).
Now guess which way the devs of this game take. Right. Number 2.

This was one of the hardest games for me in the last years to force myself to get all achievements.
But the game isn't hard. Instead it is very easy, but unnecessary long (real playtime around 20 hours) and amazingly boring.
The ground premise of the story and the first hours of gameplay were really good and kept me going.
But soon all the flaws popped up:

- While some missions tell you, there is time pressure ... there is no countdown gameplay wise.
- There is no way to arrange your screen with nearly 1/2 of unnecessary infos for the mission, 1/5 for the mission info and only the rest for the changing mission data you need to process.
- While the game has a linear story and missions, that follow up older ones, there is no database or such and using info from it in further investigations.
- The very few times, the game expands the gameplay and make it a bit more complex (for example compare infos from different suspects), it ruins this step, by not changing your possible way to process the data.

The funny thing is, that with a way shorter game length/less missions (around five hours) I would have looked other all these flaws and would have given this game a thumbs up.

review:
Absolutely incredible. Didn't run the best on my laptop. Had a couple of soft locks, but I can't tell if that's due to something with the game or if it's just my laptop. If it's worth anything, I didn't notice anything out of the ordinary before the soft locks and it didn't happen at the same part once I rebooted the game.
I'll try to keep spoilers to a minimum, especially since I can't figure out if I'm doing the spoiler formatting right and can't be bothered to write this again if I get it wrong.
I'll put a summary at the bottom where it's segmented off from the spoiler area.

Game's great. Would recommend.


---------SPOILER TERRITORY. SORRY I COULDN'T FIGURE OUT THE FORMATTING---------


The story is fairly well written. It can be a little iffy at times when it comes to the grand scheme of things, but if you hold your suspension of disbelief, mainly the idea that someone could rise through the ranks like that and that you are pretty much the lynchpin for everything that happens in the story, it works well. I do wish that there were more outs from the story as time goes by, but you can only put so many options into a game before you start over-writing it. 
While I'm talking about endings, I'll bring up probably my least favorite one. One of the final endings is just one or two sentences and then it boots you back to the main menu. I get that they weren't trying to take a side in the underlying debate in the game, but it does seem a little strange when you have dialogue choices mean almost the exact same thing multiple times in the story.
I love how the characters are implemented into the story. On Day 2 meet someone who has your back. And that same person is with you until the final major decision. He's well developed and seems almost human with the way he's written, having real motivations behind his actions that are very relatable to many people. Almost every main character you interact with has an effect on the story if they don't straight up give you a way out of the story. For those that don't give you a way out, they still plant seeds into your mind. What those seeds may be will vary and what they grow into is up to you, but the fact still remains that they have really thought the writing out.
The mechanics of the game have also been very thought out. It may look like dots on a map when you first start out, but it quickly expands when you hover over that dot. A name and a picture along with a general location does enough to put meaning into a character that will be on your screen for about a minute. And then there's more information on the person once you click on them, information that will almost never have an impact on the case at hand. As you go through their data, it plants more seeds of doubt in the system. And then you have to click one of two buttons. Do they go free, or do they not go free? No matter what button you click, there will be text that pops up. That text tells you what happens to that person. Solely because of what you decided to do. The weight behind all that is monumental at times. It makes you question your decisions at times. And it is absolutely well done.
The commentary on the security/liberty debate is where this game really shines. By establishing a connection with someone who will be on your side until the end of the game, it ensures that the line for most people will be blurred. It's story is written well enough to have it come out to you at points and ask you if what you are doing is right and warns you that it's a dangerous path that lies ahead if you continue down it. As you keep climbing the ladder at the DoL, it's not just the people around you that starts to make you question the morality of everything that happens here. That's before you start to notice that the decisions are starting to become less and less mundane as time goes by. And as it all comes to a head, there's one question in your mind:
How much are you willing to sacrifice for security?
This question meshes in well with other subplots in the story, whether it be surviving though nepotism or just trying to live a normal life. You see people early in the game have moral dilemmas when they have to do things like authorize a new technology early or have to decide on where to take their career. Adds a nice bit of background to the characters you meet along the way.


---------[END SPOILER TERRITORY]---------


All in all, this is a fantastic game. It's entertaining, has a well-written story, and has a lot of deep questions that you have to ask yourself as technology advances in today's world. Takes a bit of time to complete. It took me about 16 hours to do my first full run of it. And it was 16 hours well spent.

Final Ratings:
Story: 8/10
Need a little bit of suspension of disbelief to get the ball rolling, but once the ball does get rolling it's hard to stop it. Excellent twist that you can just straight up miss if you're not paying attention.
UI: 6/10
Hope you like dots. You'll be seeing them almost exclusively. Does contribute well to the whole computerized atmosphere of the game. Sometimes Person(s) Of Interest (POI) get lost in the southern side of the map or in places that aren't really in conventional areas (looking at you Alaska and Hawaii). Sometimes the UI overlaps itself if you click a button too early and there's dialogue or if there's a POI on the eastern side of the map in the space between the phone and what the office around you looks like. Map scrolling can be annoying, so you disable it and then it's annoying that it isn't scrolling, so you re-enable it and the scrolling gets annoying again, and then you get annoyed that you have to toggle this on and off so you just leave it one or the other an deal with it.
Music: 7/10
Can get a little repetitive with some of the longer levels, but it's pretty well written. It's electronic style fits well with the setting of the game. Musical cues also help out in some scenarios.
Commentary: 10/10
Can't go into too much detail without spoiling a lot of the game. If you don't care about spoilers, go back up and reread the section that I start by mentioning the commentary.
Overall: 8/10
It's fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561197981494710', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 58, 'playtime_forever': 1223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1223, 'last_played': 1608841556}
review:
So gerne ich auch [i]Need to Know[/i] empfehlen würde: ich kann es leider nicht. Das Werk von Monomyth Games erfüllt nach meinem ursprünglichen Preoder 2016 bei weitem nicht die Erwartungen, die der damalige Trailer gestellt hatte; derselbe Trailer, der auch heute noch die Steam-Shopseite ziert.

Während Hacking-Alternativen wie [i]Hacknet[/i] oder der Klassiker [i]Uplink[/i] durch ihre im Spielverlauf hinzukommenden Tools das Spiel immer abwechlungsreicher gestalten bleibt [i]Need to Know[/i] leider immer wieder auf demselben Level, den es zu Beginn trägt. Nachdem das Assay-Tool einmal verstanden wurde, geht es anschließend nur noch darum, die dargestellten Informationen nach Schlüsselwörtern zu durchforsten, eine Aufgabe, die sich wie Kaugummi nach einem tollen Erstgeschmack in eine erst langweilige, dann zähflüssige Masse verwandelt.

Ja, [i]Need to Know[/i] hat seine spannenden Momente. Aber andere Vertreter wie [i]Orwell[/i] verpacken diese weniger linear. Das ist der zweite Schlag gegen NtK: die Geschichte. Im Gegensatz zum 2016 versprochenen Dynamik und dem Trailer bleibt das Spiel ein linearer Strang an Einzelaufgaben. Es gibt ein paar Möglichkeiten, ein anderes Ende zu erwischen, aber diese Enden führen nach einer langatmigen (und langweiligen) Animation zum Hauptmenü, wo klar darauf hingewiesen wird, dass dies nicht das beabsichtigte Ende ist. 

Damit bleibt das Spiel das Hauptfeature, nämlich die angesprochene Entscheidungsfreiheit, vollkommen schuldig: "will you stand up for privacy, or help create an unstoppable police state?" ist keine Frage, die wiederholt während des Spiels gestellt wird; es ist eine Frage, die sich höchstens spielende selbst stellen müssen. [spoiler]Im Spiel selbst kann diese Frage nur am Ende endgültig einmal klar beantwortet werden, in der allerletzten Entscheidung.[/spoiler]

Neben diesen Enttäuschungen gesellt sich ein User-Interface, das einige Probleme mit sich bringt: Verdächtige sind zu nah beieinander, Verdächtige häufig [b]hinter[/b] der Regelliste, UI-Elemente, die genutzt werden, blenden sich selbstständig aus, das Scrollen per Mausrad ist so langsam, dass nur Drag&Drop gut funktioniert, und ähnliches. Ein User-Interface, das mit langsamen Überblendungen zum Einschlafen anregt, erschöpft auf Dauer.

Am Ende bleibt damit nur noch die Feststellung, dass [i]Need to Know[/i] eben kein [i]Need to Play[/i] ist.

review:
I have not finished the game!! This is one of the BEST dystopian simulations i've played. Similar to Orwell, as other reviewers have pointed out, but EVEN BETTER! 

Things I loved:
I love the challenge. It's definitely a game you have to pay attention to and make correct choices. 
There are different facets to the game that allows you to balance home and work life and develop numerous relationships. These are not optional. NPCs will just force you to talk through the phone or at work. 
Relevant story that builds onto itself and you are ultimately working towards the final goal which is to identify and locate Cloud Dweller ( i believe thats his alias) 
I like the characters. I like the story. It's very well written and done. And I love that I can be sassy with that dude at work that everyone hates. LOL 
It's a long and complex game. It was longer and has more content than I expected.
The dating app KILLS ME! Those profiles XD no wonder people are single.

Things I hated:
Some choices lead directly into game over. I ended the game multiple times unintentionally with no warning through dialogue selection. Like I was talking to the reporter/boyfriend/friend? Not sure of his purpose yet. Anyway, I accidentally said I worked at DoL and BAM! game over. Thankfully the autosave system allows you to log back in and pick up before you make that choice. But it was just so sudden and happened multiple times during different scenarios.
Everyone forces you to work for them. You have to keep selling secrets to keep your reputation up with everyone so they don't either blackmail you or fire you. It's annoying. I would rather have more choices. I don't like being two-faced and this game forces you to be that.

Overall - I still recommend it. I keep wanting to finish it and it has held my interest which few games do. However, I doubt I'll replay it. Either way - it's definitely worth the price! Buy it on sale if you can, but even $15 is still decent for this game.

KEEP UP THE GOOD WORK!

review:
Good game for mature children and teens, but most adults will be disappointed. The main game mechanic is "finding a needle in a haystack". Unfortunately, the haystack is tiny, and the needles are not very well hidden. You are provided a list of keywords to find in tiny documents, given basic criteria. The biggest challenge is making sure it is spelled correctly before highlighting it. I expected the game to be more investigatory, being able to follow leads, etc... this is not that kind of game.

Your character is a young adult, fresh out of college, working his/her first job. The story and the style of the dialogue was written to appeal to children. At one point, my friend in the game texts me to ask who was my high school crush. I immediately assume he is phishing for the answer to my security question to hack my password, but no. I'm overthinking. The game just does this to determine if your crush was a male or female, so it can introduce a new character into the game.

The icing on the cake for why I have to give this game a thumbs down... An anti-government group tries to extort me. There is no option to report this to the Department. I choose not to provide them any documents, because I take national security seriously, and then I lose the game. ---You must leak classified documents, or it is game over.

So much for Monomyth Games' "will you stand up for privacy, or help create an unstoppable police state?" ---Well, I'm forced to leak classified documents to terrorists, so I guess I don't have much choice in the matter.

Monomyth Games also writes, "You can also resist ... by aiding underground groups ... Or, you can just use all of that juicy classified information for your own personal gain. Your call." ---But it's not my call, because if you don't leak the classified information, it is game over.

The pitch made about the game misrepresents the actual game. I would have paid twice as much for the game if it delivered on what was promised, but as it is, I feel duped. They did a really good job on the graphics and interface design... moral dilemmas in stories are awesome, but you can't propose a moral dilemma to the player and then force a game over state if they choose to follow federal law.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037607099', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 875, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 873, 'last_played': 1627073710}
review:
I really wanted to like this game. I saw Jon from MATN on Youtube try it and it looked liked my kind of thing. While I really like the premise, how it looks and some of the missions, unfortunately the experience has been frustrating. Mostly small things, but many small things which add up to an overall frustrating experience.

My general frustrations have been:
- Cluttered screen, especially when using a laptop when the screen is smaller.
- Evidence not demonstrating what the rules require but marked as missed when not chosen. (E.g. Evidence of someone telling a suspect to buy shares, when the rule says suspect must have bought shares. These are not the same thing, but the game considers them to be.)
- Moving background makes selecting the small dots difficult and no option to turn the movement off.
- You can choose incorrect evidence yet the immediate feedback says something which suggests it was in fact correct.
- Some rules weren't fully explained either in tutorial or in Peepr so got confused especially in the beginning.
- No way to re-evaluate a suspect once you've made a decision even if the day hasn't ended.
- No way to replay a day or restart unless you log out.
- Strongbox missions are sometimes very long winded and so get fed up quickly as the strongbox only seems to allow as much evidence as you can fit on the screen without scrolling. When on a 13inch macbook it fills up too quickly.

I think this game has a lot of promise, but it needs working on before I will consider recommending it.

review: I got this game because I really loved Orwell and found it to be a thought provoking and thrilling story experience. This game, although comparable in premise, is definitely unique in its gameplay and purpose--you get prompted to "participate" (I say this loosely because your dialogue options are limited) in text/phone conversations as well as chats with your coworkers, and you can do "off the record" work from home. Like Papers, Please, more surveillance options open up as you play and there is an underlying plot. But I do have some issues with the mechanics of the game; as I mentioned before, dialogue options are very limited, and you're required to pursue certain paths in the story (you can't chose *not* to work for specific groups. You have to take all opportunities or you get a game over, which is kind of annoying). There's also some bugs and small annoying "Features"... The instructions/tutorials/exposition text all automatically progress (no "click to continue") so you can easily miss out on instructions or text. Sometimes the tutorial messages will get stuck and stop proceeding even though you've done what they've asked. Then it won't continue until you've gone ahead and figured out the tutorial section on your own. The game could use some more polish, but isn't unplayable and is fun enough.

review:
[b] Premise [/b]
You are a government employee working for the 'Department of Liberty' where your job is to spy on/profile suspects and targets. You 'match' pertinent information (dating profile, purchases, social media posts) to mission based criteria. 

[b] Play it if you like.... [/b]
If you played and enjoyed 'Papers, Please',  or 'Orwell' then chances are you'll like this game. If you like the concepts of 1984, V for Vendetta then you'll enjoy the story. And if you really just like sorting and matching information like a nerd (like me) then you'll love the gameplay

[b] Pros [/b]
Great gameplay concept and the profiling aspects are really interesting - a lot of thought has been put into these elements and I enjoyed seeing what I'd get access to next.
Progression through the 'ranks' is done at a decent pace which keeps things fresh. Theres also some evening missions to supplement your income
Theres also a nice mix of mission types - I enjoyed the 'waves' missions where you are given more information each 'wave' in order to keep or eliminate a suspect. 
Plenty of moral ambiguity to the main characters - although some are cartoonish. 
Overall story is quite compelling and I was always eager to see how it would progress (I did a lot of 'Oh I'll just play one more mission before I switch off.....')
Again, if you're an information-sorting nerd like me you'll just love the gameplay.

[b] Cons [/b]
UI is a bit painful sometimes - you can't zoom into information (you can change the UI to either 'IN YOUR FACE' or 'far away' but neither is a good compromise). For example when I had to look at a persons job on their social network it was so tiny I could barely make it out. And again when selecting suspects from a clustered area I couldn't highlight the right profile. I think this could be improved by making better use of the screen...there is SO MUCH empty space! I like to have the mission rules up all the time to match to but I constantly have to scroll through them at the bottom of the screen even though there was a huge empty space to the left of the screen totally un-used.
Story con - like a lot of these games you're given the illusion of freedom of choice. 

[b] Overall [/b]
I played the game through in 25 hours and was fully addicted to it as I was playing it. I think it just avoided getting stale mainly because the main story always kicked in at the right moments. If the UI could be sorted I'd have been so much happier.

review:
EDIT: After playing an additional 14 hours, I felt it was best to revise my original review. I can rate this game as being recommended, so long as you're okay with a few necessary compromises. I'll explain those below.

I wanted to like this game very badly, but 5 hours in and I'm starting to see the seams and cracks that make this a less than perfect experience. I think my dissatisfaction with the gameplay comes down to one question: when you played Papers, Please, was your favorite part of the game the times where you had to squint at the IDs to see if that was a D or a P or a G? If so, you'll love this game. Everyone else will be irritated, and rightfully so.

The game is beautiful - I loved the interface and the art style. The story, at least so far, is passable and engaging, and I'm conflicted about finishing the game because of its flaws and the main reason is because I do want to see how the story resolves itself, and there's an early "flash-forward" that has me intrigued about what remains to be experienced.

But when the core gameplay is "spot the difference between two letters or numbers" or "try to remember this ridiculously complex flow chart of rules and protocols", it gets exhausting. It also doesn't help that for me, the game was slow and plodding at times. Opening up a menu sometimes took 2 or 3 seconds longer than you expected it to, and visual transitions sometimes slowed to a crawl. Add to that the completely boring gameplay loops and you have a recipe for boredom.

So again, to summarize... if you have fun deciding which of these three names - P Vasquez and D Vasqez and B Vaskez - matches the one in a briefing supplied to you before the stage begins, and you can suspend your disbelief that so many people would have more than one variation of the same name in their address books, then you'll like the game. Otherwise, maybe read a plot summary.

UPDATE: I stuck with the game because of the story, as I mentioned. And I was surprised to see - well into the game - that the gameplay does get mixed up in interesting ways eventually. There are still lots of repetitive tasks that seem to be there just because, at the end of the day, this is a game and not a true simulation. But there was something to the premise and the characterization and dialogue that kept me wanting to press forward even when it was monotonous. If you think you're up for the task and have nearly 20 hours to spare, the ending is passable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036546555', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 3236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 3236, 'last_played': 1582937455}
review:
Big Brother is watching you. 

Ohne einen konkreten Lebensplan im Sack startet ihr eine Karriere beim "Department of Statistics." Hierbei handelt es sich aber in Wirklichkeit um das Department of Liberty, eine Behörde, die im Nachgang eines terroristischen Anschlags ins Leben gerufen wurde um dessen Urheber, den sogenannten "Cloud Dweller", dingfest zu machen.

Man startet erwartungsgemäß auf der untersten Stufe der Leiter - Clearance Level 10 - mit  eingeschränkten Befugnissen und Möglichkeiten und erhält mit Fortschreiten der Karriere - respektive der Sicherheitsstufe - Zugriff auf immer mehr und vor allem immer tiefer greifende Werkzeuge zur Überwachung und Bespitzelung seiner Mitmenschen. Moralisch ist das häufig sehr ambivalent, denn tatsächlich wird man im Verlauf des Spiels die kontinuierlich ausufernden Möglichkeiten immer wieder auch zum Wohl der Menschen einsetzen. Aber man sagt nicht umsonst der Teufel sei ein Eichhörnchen und im Detail steckt er ohnehin..

Schon recht früh im Spiel erhält man die Möglichkeit auch außerhalb von Arbeitszeit und Büro auf das Programm zuzugreifen und wird um "kleinere Gefälligkeiten" außerhalb des Protokolls  für die Führungsebene der Behörde gebeten. Aber nicht nur dort ist man an den Daten der Bevölkerung interessiert, auch eine Aktivistengruppe und die Unterwelt zählt plötzlich zur Liste der Interessenten.  Nun muss man nicht jede Anfrage bedienen, ein grundsätzliches "nein" ist jedoch keine Option sofern man an Karriere (und Leben) interessiert ist. Mehr sei nun aber inhaltlich nicht verraten.

Einen nicht unähnlichen Story-Plot hat natürlich "Orwell" auch schon erzählt. Persönlich gefiel mir die Geschichte in Need to know aufgrund der ganzen kleinen Nebenstränge aber besser. Musikalisch ist das Spiel während einiger Missionen mitunter fantastisch unterlegt, außerhalb dessen fiel mir die Soundkulisse nicht negativ auf.

Das Spiel ist in Englisch, der Sprache sollte man dementsprechend mächtig sein. Ich würde meine eigenen Sprachkenntnisse als sehr gut bezeichnen, musste mir das ein oder andere Wort trotz allem aber erstmal übersetzen - wer seit seiner Schulzeit also kaum noch Berührungen mit der englischen Sprache hatte, wird vermutlich wenig Freude an dem Spiel haben.

Grundlegend hat mich hier eigentlich wenig sonderlich genervt oder gestört. Gegen Ende fühlt sich das Spiel dann aber doch ein bisschen nach Arbeit an. Das, was man grundsätzlich in den Missionen tut - Datensätze nach vorgegebenen Kriterien abzuklappern und zu markieren - ändert sich im Verlauf des Spiels nicht. Man wird schlicht mit immer mehr Informationen zugeballert, was man dann damit anstellt bleibt sich im Grunde immer gleich. Jedoch macht die Geschichte das mehr als wett. Einen besonders hohen Wiederspielwert sehe ich hier ( trotz verschiedener Möglichkeiten wie das Spiel enden kann)  leider nicht. Da man während der letzten Passage bzw. nach Abschluss die finale Mission wieder neu laden kann, darf man die verschiedenen Möglichkeiten das Spiel zu beenden aber ausprobieren ohne alles nochmal von vorne starten zu müssen. Insofern ist das kein Problem. Eine klare Empfehlung von meiner Seite gibt es in jedem Fall, ich hatte eine gute Zeit mit Need to know. 

Have a nice day.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998667692', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 330, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 330, 'last_played': 1581641602}
review:
I [i]really[/i] wanted to like this game; I gave it a fair shot, and I was one of the backers before it was even released.

The problem is that absolutely nothing is done with the immensely intriguing premise. You get to make absolutely zero choices on your own most of the time; the few times I got to actually decide for myself, any decision that doesn't align with the institution you're working for immediately results in a non-standard game over. You spend most of your time playing an elaborate version of Papers, Please, where crucial mistakes that would logically result in a high-threat suspect escaping are just brushed over, you're penalized in score, and someone else checked your decisions and found that you were wrong, making me wonder why I'm even needed if someone else is going to do my job anyway.

You're constantly railroaded into conversations with no choice on your part on how they progress or where they end up. You have no choice in who to work with; if you refuse to work with someone for too long, they rat you out and you go game over. The story progresses with no input on your part, if you don't count one or two inconsequential lines of dialogue being different.

The developers of this game had a golden opportunity with the subject material the game deals with, and they seemingly chose to do absolutely nothing with it. If you enjoy seeping through very limited amounts of data, stick to rules religiously, and having no influence on events in the story whatsoever, while (falsely) being told you're a big difference-maker, bossed around and punished with a slap on the wrist at worst for crucial mistakes, then I guess I can recommend this game - for me, I'm done wasting my time waiting for the game to get interesting. Maybe it does later down the line, but five hours in, my patience has been lost.

review:
[b][i]Need to Know[/i][/b] is a surveillance simulation, the gameplay of which is somewhat reminiscent of the cold and  calculated [i]papers, please[/i]. You assume the role of an employee of an NSA-like organization called The Department of Liberty, and take care of checking people's browsing history and other personal information to identify a possible security risk. The game gives you more options and scary ways to control the longer you play and rise in security clearance. There is always an elementary question floating in the room: Do you stand up for individual rights or do you help to create an uncontrollable police state.

With its topics, [b][i]Need to Know[/i][/b] is not only closer to reality than many other games, it also creates a completely new game approach that will involve many moral decisions. The gameplay, which is basically just scanning data and making quick decisions, is very close to the border crossing simulation [i]papers, please[/i]. Nevertheless, since then hardly any studios have dared to deal with a political issue that affects us all in a similarly dry and fascinating way.

[b]THE GOOD[/b]
- Memorable characters
- Nice story events
- Wonderful atmosphere
- Highly addictive

[b]THE BAD[/b]
- Won't appeal to everyone
- Takes some trial and error

review:
The game is too tedious and boring for me to recommend. 

First off the story is definitely the best part of the game. It kept me playing until the end and had some great twists to it. The game gives you different options and choices every now and then but after i replayed some chapters the choices i made hadn't changed much. At least you can get different endings though. 

Another point in favour of this game is that its just good to look at. Music and sound is also great. It never feels cheap.

Problem is Need to Know long game that revolves around matching up information. Did a suspect mention a certain word, or call a certain person or travel somewhere on a certain day. To get through the story you have to do this over and over and over again and not much else.

I think the game could have been better if you are given the story context, some clues and then asked to make a decision of who you think is a threat or not. A few times you see something like this where you get a interrogate someone and have figure out yourself how to blackmail them based on the available information. For the majority of the game though its just boring.

review:
I backed this game on Kickstarter 3 or 4 years ago and forgot about it till now. For 15 dollars (I paid 12), this game has been worth every penny. I really enjoyed the progression of security rankings and the data and power that came along with them. I also liked the ironic naming of the Department of Liberty. The little news headlines were interesting to read and paralleled our society in a way that made me think "Could this be us someday?" 

I don't know if your overall play style affects the endgame but I chose to play as a ruthless arm of the state just to see how far I could take my power. In the end, I chose to [spoiler] become the new director of the all powerful DoL and take down Charles Douglas. [/spoiler] However, in real life I found myself disgusted at the choices I "had" to make in the name of security and personal gain. Just knowing that I was violating privacy AND potentially ruining lives was quite the experience. The people I betrayed and killed felt real and conflicting. But alas, [strike] control [/strike] ... I mean security above all else, no?

The game can be played all through a mouse. A couple times my CODEX world-map background refused to pop up until I clicked it or tried to scroll. The biometric data was a little graphically glitchy. A few times I was confused at new task assignment types but I figured it out. Overall, a polished game with little complaints especially for how affordable it is. 

It felt rewarding to see Clearance Level 1, Rank = 1st. The soundtrack was [b] beautiful, [/b] truly well composed. The game made me feel conflict and emotion which is indicative of an excellent work of media/art/etc. If you are interested in surveillance, politics, culture, RPG's, or conflict this game is for you. After my play-through, I can't help to reflect on our own society and how much this game may or may not be representative of our current (and future) society. review:
Alright where do i start. The surveillance concept is very interesting, and the realism of the whole thing made it deeply disturbing for me, which is a good thing, since it kept me on the edge of my seat many times. Gathering evidence can get tricky, there are many traps left and right, but the difficulty is fair. The UI could be better, especially in later clearance levels, where the evidence can get overwhelming. I love the art style though. The story is pretty good, although its tainted by the obvious illusion of choice.


However there are some things that i dislike very much, not because they are bad themselves, but because how the game interacts with or based on it. For instance, the game saves twice a day(ingame time) and creates a gazillion save points, which would be okay, if it were possible to load any other save point beside the last.


Very mild spoilers regarding game design:

Then, you can buy stuff, this got me excited, but it actually has 0 impact on anything aside your bank account, which again, has 0 impact on anything besides the possibility to buy stuff. So its basically a closed system of uselessness. The suspicion points are only used to 5 at max i think, the other 3 seem to be decoration until the very end game, and even then they dont affect anything either.

Spoiler End

Facit &tl;dr
Its a good game, has some flaws, but nothing major. Interesting setting, worth full price, any sale would be a steal.
If you like stuff like Orwell, papers please, beholder, you probably will like this, too.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042536082', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 1076, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1076, 'last_played': 1553386936}
review:
Very fun game that does an excellent job of portraying the slippery slope when dealing with the question of rights vs security.

*** Spoilers ***
You start off with basic tasks like hunting down murderers or catching terrorists, but then a hurricane hits...

... And you're not permitted to go snooping through people's offline data, but you break the law anyway because if you can track them down, you can send FEMA their location and save some lives! So it's fine, right? Sure, some people lose a bit of privacy, but you're rescuing them from the hurricane!

And then as you rise through the ranks you get a bit more power and you start dealing with tracking down serial killers or stopping an active shooter... But then a senator doesn't like the fact that your department is ignoring people's rights to privacy and wants to shut you down...

... So you blackmail her by digging through her data and finding embarassing information to damage her career. Can't have her foolish ideals stand in the way, obstructing your quest to save lives, right?

And then a bunch of corporations give you access to their data, making your job to track down terrorists even easier, and helping you along the way in your original mission to find a man who caused a few nuclear reactors to overload in a massive terrorist attack, but they want a couple favours...

... So you start doing a bit of corporate espionage on the side, but it's fine, I'm sure, because the backroom deals are how you make progress, and no one *really* needs to keep their shopping history private, do they?

But then some of this stuff gets leaked and more politicians start rallying against it. Fools. They don't know how hard you're working to keep this country safe! They don't know how necessary it is to use this data...

... So you launch a disinformation campaign to silence them and ruin their credibility. It was their fault anyways. They threatened the department, and you needed to protect it! You're the only one standing in the way of the terrorists attacking america, so getting your hands dirty sometimes is fine if it's to protect the greater good, right?

So throughout the game you're doing these underhanded deals, blackmail and character assassinations, but it's fine because you're catching terrorists, saving lives, and generally making sure the citizens can go on with their happy little lives. Soon it pays off! You catch a terrorist who leads you to a terrorist who leads you to a whole network of them! ... but they're scattered across the globe, and many of the countries aren't too keen on sending them to the states for judgement...

... Well they stand in your way! They're harbouring enemies of the state, that's basically an act of war, right? You need to show these governments the errors of their ways... Or maybe you can't. Maybe you should arm some of the militant groups in the countries who are more friendly towards US interests... So you start distributing arms to them and help them seize power, but it's fine, right? You toppled a government and installed a few dictatorships, but you've got to help your country! They were basically asking for it anyways by hiding your enemies, right? So what if a few thousand people on the otherside of the world got killed, you're supposed to protect Americans and that's what you're going to do!

But now your powers are growing and word of your department's actions are reaching the journalists, who are writing scathing criticisms of you and turning the people against you... Well you can't have that happen, so you need to silence them, either by getting them fired or threatening them to keep quiet! Freedom of speech is just getting in the way here, this sacrifice is for the good of the nation, right? Right?!

Despite your best efforts public opinion is still slowly turning against you, and the politicians are noticing... well there's an election coming up, so you've got to make sure a politician friendly to your department gets in. Can't have the president disband the department of liberty, there's still so much work left to do! 

... So you blackmail politicians, leak incriminating documents, and funnel support towards your prefered candidate, ensuring she wins the election. You've subverted democracy but it's fine, right? You need to protect the department because it protects the nation! You're the hero of this story after all! You can't let people who don't understand get in the way, right guys? Right?! Sacrifices must be made! It's for the good of the nation! The good of us all! There's no way I could be the villain, right?! I am the hero here!!!!

But of course, it doesn't stop there. You need more power. Even when you're launching military assaults on embassies in foreign nations, even when you drone-strike your own citizens, even when you assassinate the leaders of other countries who once tried to help you but now stand in your way... 

And then you see it. You get betrayed. People want the power your department has, and your boss and other corporations are vying for the systems that now control the world. What was a perfect, all-seeing system is being used as a pawn by people for petty power plays and revenge... to further their own ideals at the expense of everyone else. You know that you need to end this. You need to stop it. The people at the top need to be brought down. A system this powerful can't remain in the hands of those who would abuse it. A system this perfect either needs to be destroyed or to remain under the control of someone who would use it for good... someone like you... And after all, you're the hero, so why not take it? It's for the good of the nation after all... 

*** End Spoilers ***

Unfortunately there's still a few problems with the game. The interface is not nearly as responsive as it should be for as simple a game as this is. Additionally when you get assignments cross-referencing between multiple suspects,... ugh... the limitations of the UI really make themselves known, and despite there being hundreds of HCI papers out there for how to build proper interfaces when comparing data, this game chooses to use none of them. As someone who worked in an Info-vis lab for a while, I can safely say that the method they chose to link data between two different suspects is one of the most annoying and tedious ways they could have possibly done it. You will audiably groan when you see the mission rules "Link evidence when two suspects travel to the same city at the same time.". It is that bad. Fortunately these missions are few and far between, so you don't have to deal with it too often.

I also didn't like that your actions basically had no lasting effects. Any big choice either ends the game or lets you continue playing. I was really hoping that...

*** Spoilers ***
When you get betrayed, you would have a chance to work with the Snow Owl black-ops division instead of with Tripwire to work your way back up to the top. Maybe based on which faction you had a higher reputation with. They're black-ops anyways, with everything they do being classified and deniable, so helping you wouldn't be completely out of the question.
*** End Spoilers ***

That aside, the game was very fun and very satisfying to play. It played around with a lot of neat ideas, and again, I really liked the story. I also liked how it showed your progression from living in a trashy apartment and working in basically a basement closet to living in a super upscale neighbourhood and leading your own division as you progress through the ranks. I highly recommend it.

8/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197968768811', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 432, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 277, 'last_played': 1564263848}
review:
A surprisingly fun gem of a title that... if it wants to or not, teaches the players that the world is complex.

Unlike Papers Please, where if you make a mistake, you can see plain as day what you did wrong and how you can improve, Need to Know is as grey as it's central themes. There are going to be choices you have to make with incomplete information. You might flag evidence that game rejects, or ignore evidence the game was expecting you to flag- and you might do so fully believing your choice was right. There is an margin of subjectivity in this game that is wonderfully refreshing. You're not going to have all the information and you have to make choices. 

For many players this might be frustrating, fully believing you made a choice and the game just disagreed with you. But that's life. Rarely does that wrong choice fully lead to a game over and the plot itself is good enough to keep me invested. 

My biggest surprises is that this title isn't more well known. It's a solid game.

review:
I really enjoyed this game. I played it over a week or so, and couldn't wait to get home every day so I could play it. 

I ended up feeling attached to my character and her friends, which is not something you would expect during the first few hours of playthrough. Maybe it was just from being exposed to them for so long, but I liked feeling like I was actually this agent. 

I have to admit that the story component wasn't amazing, but I thoroughly enjoyed the process of selecting information on the suspects. I would have liked for my character to do more activities outside of work, and to actually be able to interact with Fyre dates through more than one conversation.

I wouldn't play it more than once, as you have the opportunity to explore several endings within one game. But I was very happy with the game overall and would highly recommend it for fans of Orwell. Also, even if you're not sure about it, try to play it all the way through! Kudos to the developers!

review:
Do not let the simple GUI fool you.  This is actually well written, thought out, and introspective.  Akin to Papers Please and other data crunching games, this actually shows a  very human side to data security.  The game not only deals with the ethical quagmires of our intelligence community, but you get to have a look under the hood of a young intel agent's life.  Balancing ethics and morals, dealing with what to do when a friend is caught up in the web, how to keep secrets buried even from family, and how people even cope with the stress and isolation (constructively and destructively).  I honestly thought this would be a $10 throwaway game (on sale), but more than a couple times I caught myself resting my cheek in my hand saying "hmmmm" to some of the situations.

Recommended.  Don't be an idiot. Get it.

review:
I like the premise and gameplay of this game, but so far - after 16 hours - the story advancement has been miniscule. And judging by the progress in "clearance levels" I'm in like half of the game. And it's pretty unrewarding and just really, really long. The core gameplay loop is pretty nice when you get different mission types or advancements in the story, but when you spread it over so many hours it becomes boring anyway.

I also believe there is an issue with difficulty, since there's no option to change it, and for the first like 4 or more clearance levels it is ridiculously easy (with one very hard mission thrown in every once in a while). But there's really no punishment for failure in story sense - you can absolutely botch an "investigation" (when you are for example looking for a suspect in waves and accidentally mark them as non-suspect in the first wave) and still succeed. Which makes sense from gameplay sense, but it's pretty immersion breaking, especially when you are still awarded with catching the criminal and such.

And coming from there - a lot of stuff in the game feels very forced. Like your "romance" / "date" or whatever just eventually appears in your apartment with no option to reject them. Sometimes you are presented with "options", but when you choose certain dialogues the game just ends (sometimes as if you almost won, and sometimes you just end up in jail and such) but in the end you always have to go back and choose the options the game wants you to.

And speaking of "going back" - there are no save slots; The game saves randomly and you can't go back. If you fuck something up because there was no tutorial or the description was misleading or you didn't get the gist of what you are looking for - tough luck, the game punishes you for that and you have to keep going forward. This issue is especially apparent with some mission types or evidence gathering that's poorly explained. One time I got everything wrong for misreading what the game wanted me to do (matching years of consecutive growth when something happens vs. matching just the last year of consecutive growth *with the thing that happened*). And there is more where that comes from.

I also encountered some minor visual bugs and UI annoyances. One of the bigger one is that "helpers" (people who you don't use your powers on and only help match evidence and such) are marked the same color on the map as the suspects. Well, some times. From the tutorial I think they are meant to be teal, but they're white like everyone else... Unless they are red for some reason, but only every once in a while (even in a single mission) before they are white again.

All in all I'm pretty conflicted in whether to recommend this game - [b]if you really like the core gameplay loop (go watch some videos) then sure, go for it[/b]. The annoyances are minor enough to really affect that too much. But [b]if you are like me, spending 16 hours to get into what is presumably half of the game with very repetitive gameplay and just tiny bits of story... You are better spending your time elsewhere[/b]. Just for comparison: I finished the whole playthrough of Prey 2017 in like 22 hours, and by the time I was at hour 16 I had discovered almost all of the story, everything about the station and Typhon, etc.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028713360', 'num_games_owned': 251, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 1776, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1775, 'last_played': 1557192945}
review:
Так, поясняю сразу, игру я получил по ключу, но ключ мне выслали потому, что я в своё время поддержал игру на кикстартере. Так что галочку "товар получен бесплатно" я не выставлял по праву. Об игре же:

Это слегка оказуаленный Papers, please с крутым графонием, если совсем уж кратко говорить.
Почему рекомендую?
1) Крутой графоний. Нет, речь не про технологии, само собой. Речь про художественную составляющую. Цветовая гамма, стиль и прочее вещи, в которых понимают только художники, дизайнеры и прочие визуализаторы. Ребята отказались от пикселей и не обосрались. Инди-игры дошли до той точки, когда за это отдельную награду давать надо.
2) Музыка. Ост скачать, конечно, не захочется, но свою работу музыкальное сопровождение делает как надо.
3) Сюжет. Он хорош.  Диалоги просты в самом хорошем смысле этого слова, персонажи в меру колоритны и не опускаются до карикатуры, а история интригует и даже неплохо так играется с вашими ожиданиями.
4) Геймплей. С одной стороны, основа не меняется. Вам даётся несколько подозреваемых. Выбираете подозреваемого, вам на стол высыпается пачка собранных Министерством Свободы улик, среди них нужно найти то, что соответствует выданному заданию и принять решение. Иногда нужно глазом зацепить какую-то заранее оговорённую деталь, чтобы на стол высыпалось больше улик, или чтобы нашлось ещё подозреваемых. С другой стороны, на этой неизменной основе создаётся достаточно вариаций, чтобы совсем тоскливо не было.
5) Самое важное на мой взгляд. Атмосфера. Или цельность. Первые четыре пункта усиливают друг друга. Так, например, одна из сюжетных веток посвящена тому, чтобы повлиять на голосование в Конгрессе по биллю, который позволит родной конторе залезть ЕЩЁ глубже в данные пользователей. Что потом открывает новые типы улик. Да и само открытие новых типов улик не только разнообразит геймплей, но и двигает сюжет вперёд. Не буду совсем уж жёстко спойлерить, но если в начале ты думаешь "о, теперь теперь в местном вотсаппе читать можно", то под конец открытие нового типа улик оказывается не только геймплейной фичей, но и инструментом для добавления напряжения в историю (N.B. ныне это модно называть саспенс). Другие изменение в геймплее тоже зачастую обосновываются сюжетно. Ну и арт-часть с музыкой тоже участвуют в этом симбиозе.
6) Ценник. Игра выглядит и звучит дороже, чем за неё просят, как на мой взгляд.

Что может отпугнуть от покупки. Особенности и недостатки. Расположены в порядке возрастания "отпугивания":
1) Продолжительность. Однозначно не недостаток, особенность. Может сработать как в плюс, так и в минус. Для меня однозначно плюс. Когда-то, во времена компании на кикстартере, они обещали, что игру можно будет пройти за 8-10 часов. Но релиз задержали на год-полтора, и в процессе прохождения я понял, почему. 25 ЧАСОВ. Именно столько ушло у меня на то, чтобы пройти эту игру. Что я могу сказать, ребята малость увлеклись. И да, у вас эта цифра вряд ли будет очень сильно отличаться. По причине описанной ниже.
2) Относительная линейность. Да, реплики в диалогах выбрать дадут, но радикально история нигде не равезветвится. К примеру, помогать местным борцам за свободный интернет всё равно придётся, даже если хотелось отыграть честного строителя тоталитарного государства. Будет несколько "досрочных" концовок, и в конце дадут выбрать из четырёх катсцен. Изначально разработчики, похоже, планировали, но не сложилось, не потянули.
3) Интерфейс + баги. Релиз ясно показал разницу между профессиональными тестерами и доброхотами с кикстартера. Поэтому первые два месяца разработчики в авральном режиме чинили хренову кучу багов (два-три десятка патчей за два месяца с кучкой багов в каждом) и шероховатостей интерфейса. Недостаток, но ТЕПЕРЬ не такой уж и страшный, так как с большего острые углы сгладили, интерфейс подвинтили, туториалов и внутриигровых мануалов добавили. Как же хорошо я сделал, что после трёх часов игры во время релиза отложил игру в сторонку и подождал пару месяцев. Здесь будет уместно сослаться на анекдот про "обработать напильником".
4) "Слегка оказуалили". Всё-таки особенность, но ценителей может отпугнуть. Papers, please подкупала ещё и тем, что заставляла работать чётко, быстро и безошибочно, попутно роняя кал. Здесь таймера нет и практически всегда тебе дают спокойно потасовать улики и подумать. Непоправимую ошибку совершить невозможно. Арестуют всегда того, кого нужно. С тебя просто снимут несколько процентов с местного счётчика профпригодности, если укажешь не на того. Когда счётчик дойдёт до нуля - гейм-овер и увольнение. С одной стороны, это делает игру доступнее. Это очень важно и это нельзя недооценивать. С другой стороны, это слегка надламывает симбиоз между геймплеем и историей. То, что арестовывают всегда тех, кого надо, а вместо ошибочных решений счётчик профпригодности, ещё можно обосновать (над одним и тем же делом работает толпа народу, поэтому твою ошибку всегда найдут и ткнут носом). А вот отсутствие таймера в тех миссиях, где согласно сюжету нужно действовать быстро, может немножко ломать погружение. Не сильно, к счастью. Тут музыка и арт-часть выручают очень сильно.

Но это именно что особенности, и для меня они игру совсем не сломали. Та же продолжительность, скорее, пошла в плюс. То, что игра развлекает меня уже больше десяти часов, и это мы ещё до середины даже не добрались, стало как раз таки очень приятным сюпризом.

review:
I wanted so badly to like this game.  I bought it with dreams of Papers Please, and Orwell dancing in my head.  While it does scratch that itch there are a few things that just turned me off of it.  

The home sections seem like padding, and are just anoying.

The later missions become needlessly convoulted to the point I was playing with a pad and pen to keep track of everything I was searching for.

This would be an amazing game if it was just streamlined a bit.
developer_response:
Hi, thanks for your encouraging words and your constructive criticism! We’re currently addressing the issues you’ve mentioned, and they’ll be improved in incoming updates.

Right now, we’re implementing and finalizing a few changes to home missions to make them more engaging, including:
[list]
[*]Adding outcomes depending on who you sell data to
[*]Additional financial pressures on your character to make the decision to sell data more pressing
[/list]
In the future, we also have other changes to home missions planned, including  more in-world impact from home missions, more impact on story, and more in-game purchasables to justify your shady dealings.
We’re always keen to hear suggestions, so if you ever have any, just let us know and we’ll see what we can do! 

At the moment, we’re also working on ways to improve Crossmatch missions later in the game, which can get a bit complicated. A few solutions we have planned are to streamline some mission rules, allow you to view two suspects simultaneously, and improve the rules panel to let you interact with rules more comfortably.

We’re delighted to read about your belief in Need to Know, and hope you keep an eye on our updates and get a chance to give it another shot. Cheers again!

developer_response:
Hi, we’re so happy that you enjoy Need to Know overall, it’s really encouraging for us! It’s also helpful for us to see your criticisms and suggestions, so we can continue improving the game.

We’re keen to add more player customization in the future, though this is complicated by the fact that Need to Know takes place over a number of years. Therefore, the protagonist ages, changes their hairstyle, and just generally develops physically, making vast-ranging customization challenging. However, we do want to add as much player choice as possible, so would love to hear suggestions! 

With mission statements, we’re always looking to improve the game and make things clearer so if you have any suggestions or issues to report, they’re very welcome over at our bug board for the game, either in the Steam discussions or on our Trello board [url=https://trello.com/b/ABG1gSZb/need-to-know-bugs-feature-requests]here[/url]. We're working to resolve confusion or any other issues as quickly as we can.

We hope you continue to enjoy the game, and we will keep working to fix issues and make the experience better overall!

review:
Edit 10/18/18:
Had to call this out: I posted a bug that broke my game onto the devs' Trello board, and they fixed it and patched it within a day! This is the kind of awesomeness I expect from game devs. Thank you guys for your hard work :)

I think I'm about halfway through with this game. It's very clear that Monomyth Games has put in a ton of time and effort into making this game really varied and fun. That being said, here are the major issues that I have with the game so far that make me closer to a "neutral" recommendation:

-UI is *very* clunky. Backing out of a profile or even trying to figure out how to end your very first day are both insanely unintuitive. This is fixable, and I have no doubt Monomyth is on it.

-Some weird prompts that have game-long consequences, but you have no idea at the time. For example, (mild spoiler) [spoiler] you get a text early on in the game asking if you used to like "Max" or "Serena" from high school. No indication at all that it's romantic, or that Max is a man. If you pick Max, you are now gay for the rest of the game. [/spoiler] Not anything major at all, but just... strange. 

-Doing "side by side" comparisons (i.e. "Try to find out the real profile, given these archived profiles of former criminals") are very hard to do, mainly because of the clunky UI. You can only have 1 profile at a time, and you can only save a certain amount of evidence to compare side-by-side at once. I wish you could have 2+ profiles open, especially since a lot of cases in the game require you to do side-by-side comparisons.

Regardless of these issues, if you're willing to have some patience for these developers, I still highly recommend the game. This game is basically "Papers, Please" but NSA-esque. You unlock more and more tools as you go along such as: [spoiler] social media posts, call metadata, audio recordings of calls, package tracking... you name it. [/spoiler]. As I said, it's very clear the company has put a ton of time into this game and want it to be fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093666838', 'num_games_owned': 560, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 86, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1537492057}
review:
[h1]Decide the fate of citizens of the world in this surveillance thriller![/h1]

You start the game by creating your character. Only gripe I have here is that there aren’t many choices as far as looks goes. It’d be nice to have more than one face type for the male and female. After that, you go through a very detailed tutorial that goes through the basics of what it will take to get you through the job you’ll be tasked with.

The game is deals with a story that’s shaped by your choices as you completed various assignments, gather evidence, flex your powers, and gather profiles. You don’t have to snoop either. As you progress through the game, you’ll have various choices that will allow you to take a stand against the very government organization you work for. A regular in-game cyber revolutionary. 

However, doing more for your boss means a higher clearance level and a higher clearance level means unlocking cooler (albeit creepier) powers, once classified information, lots more money and of course, prestige. With a higher salary, you can impress or intimidate your peers with purchases like new homes and more.

The game play is slow, but goes as fast as you want it to. I mean that in the sense that if you’re the type like me that combs through evidence and meticulously pieces together a person's profile, this will be the game for you. The main story clues are littered throughout your missions. So keep your eyes peeled. 

The music fits the narrative and the UI is clean. The developers are constantly listening and are active on the Steam Discussions. So, if there is a bug you come across, post to the Discussions and you can be sure a developer will take your problem into account. The only bug I came across was the weird save bug where my game would not save, but after a few updates, the saves are working.

I backed the game, but it's $14.99 and runs about 8-10 if you’re not rushing through it. You can definitely stretch that time out by investigating and going through the side content of which there’s a good amount of. The developers have said they plan on adding more content after the game’s ending and that you will be able to continue after your end of game save.

I recommend Need to Know: The Mass Surveillance Thriller Game. If you enjoy intrigue, espionage, and tools at your fingertips for finding out people’s secrets, then this game is for you. It’s a slow burn that works your detective skills and you can be either for or against the government. The game still has a few bugs, but the developers are quickly churning out updates and changelogs that address concerns.
