author: {'steamid': '76561198154477226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 5537, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1976, 'last_played': 1648461724}
review:
So I was one of the people who tracked this game from pretty much the start. I backed it because I loved the idea of the setting and the Papers, Please-style gameplay. Now that I've finished the final product I can say I got both a little more and a little less then I anticipated.

So let's start with what was good.


From what I saw this game looked like a 1984-style distopian future game. It seemed like you would play as an evil institution with no goal but to moniter what people think. As it turned out, the game made it much more complicated, in a good way, that is.

The final product had a story far more intriguing then what I expected. As it turns our, the DoL (That's Department of Liberty, the department you work for) Does infringe on the privacy of everyone, but it also stops criminals, terrorists and even helps people deal with a natural disaster at one point. On the other hand the system can also be abused. even by yourself if you so desire. Still, there is acctually a bit of an argument for the work you do in this game. I expected it to be very one-sided but the game proved me wrong.

Aside from that, watching your character change over time, getting richter and with that more morally flexible, is also a lot of fun. As you rise trough the ranks of the game the department also pulls more and more power towards it. The change from the current world to an all-monitoring police state doesn't come instantanious, but slowly, as I imagine it would in reality as well. The story took me about 40 hours to complete.

Lastly, on the list of good things are the suspects. Every one of them has a personal profile and getting and image of who they are by reading through their ever-increasing personal information is also a lot of fun. Without giving to much away, you sometimes get to know stuff about suspects that they don't even know themselves.


Now on to the stuff I expected more from.

So the gameplay looked like it would be very fun. You sort through every suspect and decide if they're dangerous or not. Now this is pretty much what you do, and it starts of being a lot of fun, but the gameplay is very slow to add new elements. It takes very long before the game becomes more challanging. Also maybe it's because I played the game quite intensively, but it got a little boring after a while. To me the gameplay started to feel like a chore near the end. I believe they should have made more variety in the missions by adding more stuff. I tended to stop playing the game when the gameplay got too dull for me. Then after a while I'd go back to it for the story.

There is also the fact that there is no timer. You can take as long as you want to finish your mission. I'm personally a little split on this fact. On the one side, I'm glad you can just take your time. I personally get quite stressed when a game gives you a timelimit and I'm pretty sure I'm not the only one on this. I also like that you can just take your time and learn all about a suspect if you like. It gives you a chance to enjoy all the detailed profiles that are in the game.
On the other side I do feel like not having a time limit makes the game a little easy. Mostly at the beginning you can just do most missions flawlessly because there is no limit to how long you can take reading about a suspect.

So if you're looking for a game with a really intriguing story and are willing to put up with getting bored of the gameplay a little from time to time, I would advise getting this game. The story really is great and it totally made the game worth it for me. If you want to buy this game for the gameplay, maybe try playing the Alpha or Beta version first and see if you would like more of that. And when I say more I mean quite a lot more.

review:
Having waited a long time since the Kickstarter ended I was really excited for this game. Then in the first playthrough I failed the Tutorial... which was surprising, I didn't think that was possible to do that. My first game was a mess, particularly due to the scaling of UI and the controls were not very clear. I failed the timed mission and wasn't really getting into the story at all because of frustration. 

Maybe a day or two later update 1.14 came through and it changed everything for the better. I can see everything in the foreground/background, stop the map from spinning the targets out of view and actually focus on the tasks. 
Having reached CL9 things started to actually matter and my character was making the shady deals I'd hoped for from the initial kickstarter description. These choices were a big part of the pull of this game for me. Do I sell Torrent users data to the DoL Agent to buy the Camera Drone, or sell instead to the underground hackers aiming to expose the DoL system? Should I help my sister with her money trouble before she will admit about it to me, what if I don't?

The game is good, better after the first hour definitely. Many people mention Papers, Please and I can see that too. Once you get past CL10 and the missions start to open up a bit it is a much better experience, I'm looking forward to breaking into CL7 very soon.

Also, for now, Monomyth are updating things pretty regularly and making noticable differences to the performance and interface for Need To Know. Its worth a try!

review:
Very much enjoying this game so far! Great scripting, interesting storyline, unique cartoonish style that matches the theme of the game! I have become quite engrossed with the characters and their interactions. There has been a lot of thought gone into making these characters seem realistic and this game has already touched on some unsettling aspects related to mass surveilance within the first hour of gameplay.

The game has been easy to play and I didn't fail the interview (think of Men in Black alien test)! Not sure if this is because the devs fixed the tutorial thing, but I have had no problems so far - it has all seemed pretty straight-forward to me! 

The missions have been quite fun. I'm still at clearance level 10, but I can see how this will get harder. So far I have encountered one bug, but I signed out then in again and it was fine. Obviously as more updates come through this will be less frequent, but once I was into the third mission I had already forgotten!

I think the UI is supposed to represent a work-desk and I quite like the style. I'm playing on a big screen and I know where I need to focus becuase it's pretty clear when the phone is to be used, and when other various controls are to be used. If I'm in doubt, all I've needed to do is click or hover and discover different aspects to the controls. I appreciated the artistic license used in screen composition when the dialogue is going on.

So far I have gotten a little bit impatient with Peepr, i.e. when I had to sign back in, but you can click and the dialogue goes faster. Added functionality with the skip option would be nice but so far this has been minor for me.

I did not follow the kickstarter campaign but a friend recommended it to me because I often like a game with a story to tell - and Need To Know hasn't disappointed me thus far! I'll update this review as I play more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069190746', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 2361, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 636, 'last_played': 1699810066}
review:
I feel the need to review this now of all times, during the stream of update. Need To Know is fantastic, but it had glaring flaws at launch. I don't believe that this is cause for negative reviews, especially since so many people tend to make a review, and never change it. So here we are.

The game itself is great. Fantastic story, interesting gameplay in the realm of Papers Please/Orwell (Wow bet you've never heard that one before), and compelling decisions, such as the option to weasel your way out of major financial pits by looking at the person who you'd be paying's profile. 

But it was a bit...unclear at first. I spent a lot of time figuring out how to work certain features, as when I first started playing, there had been no updates. No updates, no bug reports, nothing. I was on a 5 hour plane ride, which turned out to be the best time to learn, because I had the time and patience to do it. Once I hit ground, there was already a post about the upcoming stream of updates, bug reports, and immediate fixes and additions to the game to help with clarity.

As of posting this, there have been about 9 updates the help with clarity and bugs. Some may see this as a lack of playtesting. I see it as the devs being incredible accomodating and helpful. You can test a game for months, and still come out with bugs and issues that you didn't foresee because your testers just weren't indicative of EVERYONE playing the game. It happens. And these guys were prepared to handle any complaints. 

From the time I put the game down because of how I was stuck on the first Evidence Wave mission, to the time I picked it back up a day and a half later, major steps were taken to make even that mission in particular less brutally confusing. It's a walk in the park now, and a great introduction to the level style. 

All in all, this is more of a positive review of the devs than a positive review of the game. Because the game is phenomenal, and will continute to get better. The devs just happen to be...well, better than most that I've had to deal with.

author: {'steamid': '76561197966115004', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 490, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 449, 'last_played': 1536599054}
review:
I've enjoyed this game when it's made sense, unfortunately as you progress it gets more and more convoluted and less and less consistent in the results it gives you.

Firstly, the lack of tutorials is a glaring omission, having to try and work out what you're supposed to do can be frustrating at times.

Secondly: The interface is unresponsive and a bit of a mess. Having to cover a chunk of your screen real estate with the 'requirements' panel makes it hard to look at evidence and requirements at the same time, and having to click on your badge to start the mission with no hint whatsoever is a massive oversight.

My major bugbear however: Sometimes you miss evidence because it wasn't actually in the requirements. Other times, you flag evidence that matches the requirements, but apparently one or two specific pieces don't count. The most infuriating example of this I found was when a name was misspelled - an O had been substituted for an A, which led me to believe that it wasn't a match for what I was looking for (often homonyms or similar spellings are used to try and throw you off). In this case, it was an actual spelling mistake that had somehow made it through to the final product. Errors like this are a dealbreaker for me - It adds too much of a random element to the game, especially when the penalties for missing something or getting something wrong are so severe.

About those penalties: Get everything right from a pool of 18 and you'll get a modest boost, miss a couple of things out of a pool of 20 and you lose a ton of points. Balance is totally off, and because it's a 100% scale, knocking it out of the park early on doesn't buffer you against getting screwed by inconistent missions later on.

Bugs-wise, the only ones I've seen so far are message alerts on your phone flashing up so quick that you'll miss them if you blink, and a conversation going on whilst I was supposed to be doing something else. Nothing game-breaking yet, but I wouldn't be surprised if I found something more problematic in future.

Until the inconsistencies are fixed, I can't recommend this game. It's frustrating, as it had so much potential and I really wanted to like it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011229784', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 1234, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1234, 'last_played': 1535942040}
review:
Okay, so here we go. I've reached up to CL 3 now and have played the alpha version of this game as well. It's quite a bit of fun and I'm enjoying it.  PLEASE TRY THIS GAME. THE GRIND PAYS OFF.

Pros:
Neat concept, reasonably well executed by what I understand is a fairly novice indy team.
Developers are fixing the bugs
The art style is neat  (was kind of getting tired of Indy game meaning pixelart)
The CODEX facts are kinda funny sometimes and the little easteregg info bits are a nice touch.
The story is reasonably engaging
Fun sort of puzzle-type game
Doesn't feel like papers please
Hope to see new stuff get added in future as Devs are being fairly responsive to community input
The UI is well-optimized (especially when compared to the Beta)
Soundtrack isn't bad either.
The characters do actually feel like real people.
Cons

Sometimes the rules aren't always super clear and this can lead to some serious mission screwups (however, fret not, even if you get a huge compliance ding you can either A) exit the mission before going home (this will restart it from the login screen or B) Just eat the compliance hit because usually the next mission is more forgiving it's usually a couple easy missions then a kind of tough one and then a few easier ones)

The missions can feel a little grind-y. 

There's some stuff missing that seems like it should be there (There's no stock trading system as promised, the shop only has a handfull of items to buy, no cars or anything like what was in the original trailer for this game).

The first couple CLs are a grind. I've got almost 17 hours into the game and I'm at CL 3 (you start at 10). The real fun doesn't really start until about CL 6 or so and I think that's pushing a couple people away from the game.

The Data selling thing is just kind of super annoying and stretches the gameplay out unnecessarily while adding little to the story.

Wish there were more character customization options. 


TL;DR: Neat indy game, responsive development team. Can be a little grind-y through the first bit but gets pretty good after that.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990285609', 'num_games_owned': 180, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 2119, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1965, 'last_played': 1542508431}
review:
[h1]What is this game?[/h1]
It is the foremost NSA-watch-the-world-from-an-office simulator you will find as of the time of writing this review, and possibly for a long time.

You play a young man, joining a government agency. The rabbithole goes deep, and you are thrusted into a position of Orwellian surveillance, intrigue and thrill.

Starting at the bottom, you analyze simple things. Metadata, browser history and try to piece together a puzzle that is very clearly Need To Know. Given only slight glimpses of what is truly going on in this world. As you progress, you will advance in rank, getting a higher and higher level of clearance, and quickly find yourself face to face with the choice of whether or not to use your access for the good of the agency, the government, the country. the people or even yourself. 

Utilizing your powers of cyber-espionage to predict and even outright uncover your flings interests and hobbies, getting the IRS to get off your back, finding your sister/brother during an emergency or even getting out of paying your rent.

It very quickly becomes apparent what kind of power it actually is you are trusted with, and you will immediately realize why exactly it is so dangerous if left unchecked.

Don't just take it from me. Take it from the very person who knows this the best when he retweeted the game
[i]"Art imitates life."
~Edward Snowden[/i]

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
The graphic artstyle of this game is great. It's minimalistic, but still detailed in the way it is done. The whole layout gives a sense of a point-and-click adventure, and for all intents and purposes it is.

Graphically, this game is unique in the way it focuses on the mechanics and uses the art direction to enhance them. You're never distracted by what's on the screen or in your peripheral vision, yet even after many hours (I'm writing this after a 24 hour bender on this game) it never ceases to be interesting or captivating. Artistically, it's very clear it was drawn by somebody who is passionate about the game, and it shows.

[h1]Gameplay & Mechanics[/h1]
The game had a very rough start at launch, with virtually no tutorial. That has been corrected. The team behind this game are very active both on the games own Subreddit, taking into account all the reports being thrown at them and have now rolled out the fourth daily patch in a row. Where else do you see that?

The gameplay itself is good. However, I will be the first to admit that it can be un-intuitive. They have and still are taking steps to improve on this, but the game itself doesn't suffer that heavily under the previous or current issues. It plays like one would very much expect of a game of this type, yet it manages to do [i]so much[/i] with the established fundamentals of the game. Despite having pre-ordered this the moment I saw it almost half a year ago (it has been in development since 2016 and undergone many redesigns), I was honestly afraid that it would end up like most games of this caliber do, where you end up feeling the developers grasping at straws, and the game for its breath as it tries to reskin the same old mechanics and play them off as changes to the gameplay. The gameplay [b]does not change[/b], and thats strangely enough the charm and appeal.

Connect the dots as you chain together events from mere fragments of information such as e-mails, texts, social media, phone calls, browser history, bank account transcripts and decide the fate of the very people you've been spying on from behind your screen. Will you label them a threat for speaking their mind in, what they assumed to be total privacy and confidence, or will you stand up and become a whistleblower and help bring down this omniscient, omnipotent government entity?

You do unlock new abilities progressively as you pass through the ranks of this fictional quasi-NSA government agency, but they do not change the way the game plays, only improve and enhance upon it. All too often do you see games desperately trying to change its own formula throughout the span of the game, and it more often than not ends up sweeping the rug out from under themselves. You won't find that here.

I have never been much for point-and-click games. So much so that I own none except for Orwell and Need to Know. If you have played Orwell, you will without a doubt find yourself enamored with this title.

On a final note, I'll add that there is a story. Getting into it here wouldn't do it justice, and I haven't even completed the game yet. But it will draw you in. Seemingly unrelated events tie together into something larger, and as you scale the ranks of this clandestine government, denying counter-surveillance groups information (or perhaps supplying it yourself), so does the plot thicken and grow.

I would most definitely recommend this game to pretty much anybody who likes a captivating experience.

It is not without flaws, but the developers have rolled out daily fixes since release, and are obviously very passionate about this game. It's not early access, but it isn't a triple-A polished and buffed product, either. But it is getting there.

We’ve identified impactful decisions as a key area for improvement, and have already begun to address it. As well as other bug fixes and changes so far, we’ve: 

[list]

[*]Added more dialogue branches to conversations after work missions, to react more naturally to your decisions and performance in missions.
[/list]

We’re continuing to adjust home missions (as well as other aspects of the game). In future (among other things), we intend to: 

[list]

We can understand how being forced to repeat the same parts of the game would have been frustrating, and this shouldn’t be an issue now. If you fail a mission, you can restart at the beginning of that day, and the entire opening sequence up until the first work day is now skippable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198036002183', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1535776877}
review:
The game description says: "You must spy on people’s deepest secrets, pick apart their private lives, and determine how dangerous they are. You can also resist these suffocating privacy invasions by aiding underground groups in leaking data to the media. Or, you can just use all of that juicy classified information for your own personal gain. Your call."

I took this statement literally, and after my first major 'choice', I was told I failed and the game returned to the menu screen.

Now don't get me wrong. I have no problem with fail conditions in games, or even perma-death consquences to actions, but this fail condition was so illogical that it is [i]exceptionally[/i] unique amongst my experiences with video games and choice-driven RPGs. It went like this:

[spoiler]Civilian privacy protection group (TripWire) asks me to sell classified data to them instead of to an internal operative within the department itself. When they ask, I refuse.

Nevermind what you tell them, the game adds them to your buyer list anyway and assigns them a relationship meter. 

When I don't sell data to them the very first time I have the opportunity, and the relationship meter reaches 0, I get this text at the game-over screen:

"TripWire became dissatisfied with your lack of assistance and notified the Department. You have been arrested for treason."

Arrested for treason....for [i]not[/i] selling classified government data to an outside group.[/spoiler]

Choice is expressly offered in the game description, but the choices are pointless when they merely determine [i]if[/i] you can continue instead of [i]how[/i] you continue.

Couple this with a lot of bugs, lack of tutorial and cluttered, clunky UI, and I simply can't recommend it in it's current state.

The game shows promise, but it needs polishing.

Our wonderful community has combed through the game and helped us resolve spelling errors, and if we’re alerted to new ones, we try to deal with them immediately. 

The same is true for bugs, which we’ve largely eradicated. The annoying problems you had with the map nodes and buyer relationships should also now be resolved.

We’re delighted that you enjoyed the plot, and that you took the time to share your thoughts. We’ll continue to regularly update and improve Need to Know, and hope that our changes so far go some way to justifying your faith in us.

review:
I'm gonna change my review to positive, because I can see the devs care for their game and they are  fixing the issues. The game still has flaws, but it's heading in the right direction.
Currently I'm CL 8, here are my fidings.
- As I see until now there is no punishment for making bad decisions, unless you kinda miss all the clues, where it can go game over. The only downside so far is to get less salary, still you can't do anything effective with the money you make other then decorating your house, or paying off the rent or helping your family.
- On the other hand I was sitting on 100% compliance for a couple of days, and i didn't get any benefit from it. Initially i thought you move through the levels according to your performance, but unfortunately it's all scripted. I understand it would be difficult, still a nice change if the devs could implement this.
- There is no pressure, no engagement. The time stops at 5pm and waits until you finish all the suspects, no matter how slow you are.
-There is no real weight of your decisions, as everything seems scripted. You get updates after each mission, what happens with the profile of the suspects. Still it's so irrelevant, probably you won't even remember what was in their profiles, and even if they appear ingame later, you won't remember that you've already seen them. (Or it might be only me) Maybe would be nice to implement a summary of DoL record for the suspects, stating your findings and the actions taken. 
-Mission 3 was a so called speedrun, still it doesn't seem any different than the other days.
-The whole game is really slow paced, feels sluggish. CL 10 and 9 is way too long for the amount of diverse actions you can do. It feels much like a grind.
- As a lot of others, I don't like the UI either. I think there are too many irrelevent staff on screen while you are in mission (Phone, ID, building, office), they all take space from the important infos, i struggle to have all the data and the rules for the mission on screen. Also I hate that the map is moving, it just gives an extra level of frustration, that i need to drag the map between profiles.
Sorry devs, I need to compare it to Papers, please. Need to know has a much wider scale, potential and story, still PP has much  more flavor, and there you can really feel the weight of your decisions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009343662', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 1524, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1440, 'last_played': 1699471155}
review:
EDIT: After many hundreds of updates, that i missed due to being distracted by other shiny games, I have come back to this to find it much overhauled, with every complaint I had before addressed. I find the new time limit on the out of work jobs a bit of a pain, considering if you dont give the two groups what they want the game ends. Along with the fact there isnt really a pause option it makes these sections a mad rush to finish so i can leave the game to do real life things; like use a bathroom, or eat.

ORIGINAL REVIEW BELOW
tl;dr buy after a few updates or a sale.

First of all I will point out I enjoyed most of this. The visuals are clean, its reasionably easy to move on and i loved the first few missions.

Unfortunatly it all goes to pot around clearance level 8 with the damn crosslink missions. They are possibly the most frustrating things I have ever met in my entire life!

The most annoying thing about them is if you click on a 'suspect' then you CANNOT click off them without making a decision as to thier guilt or innocence. This is okay for the first dozen or so missions as all the info you need to make that choice is present on that particular characters BIO. The problem with the crosslink ones is if you click on a suspect straight away you have no option of actually finding the linking info or even who the non suspects are or anything about them. This is confounded by the fact you can only store THREE pieces of infomation in your little cloud storage area. Really, you really thought that was enough? That means you cant even collate all the data you want to maybe link to! And thats if you are lucky enough to click on those people in the first place! 

Add to the fact that the game makes wierd decisions about what it thinks is suspect infomation and you are frequently told you were wrong for very arbitary reasons. Thank god the game autosaves BEFORE your mission starts and AFTER you head home so be prepared to save-scum a LOT.

Add this to the small irritations that I can usually brush off in games, How slow the menus are, the lack of space you have to fit stuff on (like the bottom tab bar that tells you what to look for), the fact everything the suspects do apparently happens at exactly the same time and date (time travel!?!), plus some others i didnt conciously notice but are nagging at me even now and i simply cannot recommend this game at this time.

Save your money, wait for updates.
developer_response:
Hi! We’re glad that you enjoyed Need to Know as a whole, but apologize for the more frustrating aspects. Since release, we’ve been hard at work to address various problems, and the game has come a long way in that time.

The cross-linking missions have been improved since release, and will be overhauled further. Right now, you only need to make decisions on one of the two linked suspects, and these suspects are divided into two pools: Helpers and Targets. These different suspect types are now clearly marked on the map, so you’ll have to spend far less time searching through profiles to find the right connections. 

The Strongbox capacity has been expanded from three to ten slots, and will also be more easily navigable in an upcoming update. 

Several of the other problems you mentioned have been largely resolved. Along with many other fixes and changes, we’ve: 

[list]
[*]Added a UI scaling setting, which now sets all windows much smaller as a default, and allows you to adjust the size with a slider to fit your preferences. You now have much more room to navigate the evidence, and clutter should no longer be an issue.
[*]Considerably sped up menu and gameplay animations,
[*]Addressed time and date inconsistencies in evidence.
[/list]

Thanks for your kind words regarding the visuals and early missions, as well as your honesty about the game’s issues. We'll keep working to improve the game, and we hope you have another chance to play Need to Know, and that you enjoy the updated experience far more!

author: {'steamid': '76561197992168039', 'num_games_owned': 1240, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 111, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1536690389}
review:
This is not an easy game nor a polished one. I sense the direction of this game was focused towards a giant sandbox of snooping and somewhere along its devcycle someone said, "Hey, this isn't a game." Then someone else said, “Okay, we have all these things the player can do. Read emails, check contacts. Put people on watchlists… How do we make this into a game?” 

The answer of course was to have the player click on links, clicking on the right ones giving  the player points, or if they got it wrong taking points away. But that was too simple, and not very fun, so they added a couple tools to click on the links in different ways and it made it better. And the Devs (who by this point knew exactly how to use each different link clicking tools) said, “Behold! Fun!” And that’s probably as far as playtesting ever got; to the point where the small team of developers had fun playing their own game. 

This is always a problem with small indies with big visions,  they didn’t have time to playtest and get substantitive player feedback. And the biggest problem this game actually has is that the player doesn't receive feedback until  they’ve already failed. Of course, you can review these mistakes after you've failed, but with all the data you need to take in, it is difficult to parse exactly what you did wrong or even how you failed in some cases.

Despite these problems,  this game has there is a good core gameplay loop and a pretty fascinating story. KtK is a competent game in many senses and does not deserved to be tossed aside as a bad game when it is simly missing satisfying feedback.

With time I imagine this game’s player feedback will be fixed. And if it ever is, I would wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone with an interest in "connect the dots" style gameplay and Snowden Era cyberspying.  Right now, the only people I would recommend it to are people who not only love the genre and click on the right thing mechanics, but also have a high tolerance for failing and vigorously studying their failures and don't mind reading forum posts to figure stuff out.

Edit for patches: The developers have accomplished a lot in making the early gameplay more intelligible.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034977203', 'num_games_owned': 162, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1037, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1037, 'last_played': 1535567351}
review:
This game is not without it's problems, but for it's price, and the assumption that the problems will be fixed, I personally think it's worth a playthrough, especially if commentary on Orwellian government is something that interests you. Having finished the game once, I'm unsure if there are points of divergence in the story, but I do know there are conditions where
you fail and have to restart, and there are in fact multiple endings.

Pros:
-Engaging storyline.
-Pretty interface, actually makes you feel like you're sitting in an office doing this stuff.
-Simple, easy to follow gameplay, most of the time.
-Lots of different actions you can take make it feel like you're doing different things even though you aren't really.
-The mission where you interrogate the guy was REALLY fun and I wish they had more of those.

Cons:
-Gameplay can be frustrating at times, particularly on a certain mission type where it's unclear which power you are meant to use to Discard/Ignore/NoMatch people, and using the wrong power makes you lose compliance.
-Minor spelling errors littered throughout the game.
-Certain parts ("post-mission missions") can be really boring, but they are fast and even skippable.
-Certain bugs, but nothing gamebreaking. For instance, there was one case of 3 pieces of evidence having to be linked, but you can only link 2 at once.
-Clarity on which tool to use could be better, but that's more my fault on not paying attention.
-Interface clunky at times.

Overall, I'd say 6.5/10. This game, like I said, is not without it's flaws, but they can be corrected, and if you like the concept and you liked Papers Please, you'll have a fun time with this. The pros do outweigh the cons, though it can be a bit of a slog to get through sometimes and it can be a bit frustrating. At the end of the day, for 15 bucks, it's worth a playthrough.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994425275', 'num_games_owned': 507, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1011, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1554839556}
review:
In a nutshell: A good game, with some great ideas, that needs some polish on the execution, with a number of technical and interface issues that drag down a good story and a great idea.

Put simply, the idea of a game where you move through the hierarchy of a sinister spying agency is a great one, and this game's greatest success so far in my time with it has been not only showing how quickly the power to snoop on everything and everyone can go wrong, but also, and crucially, how it can still also be a force for good. The story is I think the strongest point of the game for me, because it's depiction of the ironically named 'Department of Liberty' is not really as some cartoon villain 'Illuminati conspiracy' but as a government organisation set up in response to a great crisis which, at least initially, is comprised largely of ordinary people. Sure, some of the people you meet in the game are dubiously motivated at best, but the game reinforces in the narrative consistently that there are good people in the DoL, who genuinely believe the spying they engage in is justified and indeed, there are examples in game where the power you use does make a real difference.

I can't say much more without spoiling the hell out of the game, but suffice it to say, if story is what you want, the game offers an intriguing story, and while it may not be a Tom Clancy tale, I've found it engaging and compelling.

Likewise, the gameplay offers good challenge, requiring you to carefully dissect the data you sift through, looking not just for keywords early on but as time goes on, looking for more complicated and easily missed details, like tracing suspicious bank activity with logs of suspicious contacts, and working out if they match up or are a red herring. These shifting challenges do a reasonably good job of building on each other, with each clearance level you go through iterating on previous challenges with an extra layer of complexity, and this organic growth of difficulty is largely well-executed. But it does lead into the big problem in the game: communication.

This game has a real problem communicating with the player, and I think it's largely down to an interface that can be clunky and unintuitive. Partially this is down to bugs, like notifications on your phone not displaying so you're left staring blankly waiting for something to happen, to more egregious errors like typos in the keywords you're looking for, and contextual menus being hard to close once opened and obscuring the screen. These are all fixable issues thankfully, and while irritating, they don't for me drag the game down too much, but the sooner they are resolved, the better, and they are likely to irritate some players too much to continue.

Also, the game can be ambiguous in what the objectives of each day actually require. For instance, you might be asked to look for keywords, but the game isn't good at indicating whether you need a literal, case-sensitive match of the word, or a contextual match. For instance, if the keyword was 'Bomb Kit' and you saw a log that said 'making my own bombs in a kit', you might well flag that as suspicious, and logically, it totally is, but because the game is looking for a case-sensitive, exact match, it marks you down as wrong for it. Again, these issues are not exactly common, but they're infrequent enough to annoy, and for me are the biggest issue of all in the game, but again, can be fixed by the devs.

So in the end, I recommend this game, but I do it with an advisory: if you want a good story, with fun challenges and an engaging concept of government intelligence and the morality of that, then I highly recommend it, but make sure you go in right now knowing there are currently technical and design issues, and while these will likely be fixed, as of the time of this review they exist, and they can annoy. Hopefully you'll be like me, and able to see through the roughness to the diamond within, and enjoy the experience for what it is, not what you necessarily would like it to be.

EDIT: I changed from not recommended to recommended. Because the game (tactics) change after reaching clearance level 8. Still the below criticizm is applied, but for a game with this pricetag it doesn't to that bad.

So i was hyped for this game from the start & a early kickstarter funder, but it feels like a disappointment for now.
I specially played this game for a few hours to see if it just has a slow start. But sadly it doesn't only have a slow start.. It keeps slow (might even call it boring). 
Only positive note i have at this moment is, that the story is well written and has some noticable real life scenarios.

Another bad thing (in my opinion) is the time it takes to unlock new ablilities. This only happens when you reach a new/higer clearence level. 
I have more then 4 hours into the game. And i only just unlocked clearance level 8 and therby new abilities. This takes to long in my opinion..

The game has the "beta" feel all over itself. Feels cluncky, UI is horrible to work with & windows get blocked constantly. Rules window should be movable at least.
Crashes at weird moments and nothings happening at the same point after restarting the game.

Also the evidence that needs to be collected, can be very conflicting. The rules states that something needs to be collected. But it it isn't directly linked to your suspect but a contact. The game states that you made a wrong choice.

Just as many i was hoping for a "Papers, Please" like gameplay and challenge, but than in a intelligence styled jacket.
This game is disappointing on all fonts:
- Gets boring soon, game also needs some kind of speed mode.
- Sometimes very unclear/conflicting what kind of evidence needs to be collected.
- You get new ways to check on people but no new tools to use, but only whit new clearance levels.
- Just point and click/memory playstyle. I miss some sort of typing involved (for example keyboard shortcuts), playing as an analist.

review:
I really wanted to like this game.  I love the premise, I love the feeling of detective work and secret-selling, and the narrative for me was more interesting and less stressful than Papers Please, which is easily the game it most resembles.

Unfortunately, the game is buggy, and on top of that, the process of identifying evidence or tying pieces together is so painfully unintuitive that it kills the enjoyment.  On top of that, the pace is absolutely glacial.  Assuming the idea is that you are working your way up from a rookie at the alternate universe NSA to ultimate shadow broker, I expected to be quite a bit further than 3 levels in at the six hour mark.   How much of that time was eaten up by really pointless missions that don't seem to tie into the narrative or plot?   Quite a bit.

And then there's the penalty for failure.  Woe unto the one that misunderstands the instructions for how to handle your pieces of evidence.   If you don't figure it out, you can lose a metric crap-ton of "compliance", which is the game's meter for how well you're doing.   I went from 97% compliance to 33% in a single mission.  It doesn't really give you much partial credit - if you recognize something is off about a person, but you don't mark it exactly correctly, it's nearly as bad as missing the clue entirely.   

I think that's what's really broken about this game at the end.  The part where you know in your gut when someone is clearly a problem or dangerous, but the game doesn't seem to recognize your efforts and punishes you for trying.   Having worked in government, I can say that's accurate in terms of simulating the job experience, but it's not fun.   Not at all.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045516664', 'num_games_owned': 371, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 114, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 114, 'last_played': 1535501115}
review:
[quote]Edit Saturday, November 3, 2018:
As a Monomyth developer posted below this review, this game has changed a lot since it's release and since I wrote this review. While I do not currently have time to give the game another shot due to classes, keep in mind that the review below is not an accurate reflection of the current version of Need to Know.
[/quote]

So I tried to like this game, I really did, and I was one of the ones who followed the hype from the first trailer release in the Kickstarter campaign. I really looked forward to the Papers, Please -eqsue surveillance game that the trailers advertised. Holding out to release (remember, no pre-orders!), however, revealed some key flaws that the game has.

[h1]Lack of Tutorial[/h1]
The lack of a tutorial is my primary issue with Need to Know. With almost zero instruction given, the player has no clue on how to progress, how to use the different tools provided in-game, and what distinguishes a subject between a "safe" individual and a threat. Players are expected to know beforehand what all the tools do and how to use them effectively, and  with the game not arming the players with that knowledge, I and many others were left confused as to what to do almost constantly.

[h1]User Interface[/h1]
The current user interface is extremely similar to the user interface that was advertised throughout the developer cycle. While it seems to be extremely sleek and inviting, don't let its looks fool you. The UI was another primary issue with Need to Know. In practice, the UI was sluggish and huge on-screen, with every single element in each window being blown up unnecessarily. Everything except any back or close indicators, which took minutes to find on several occasions. In the beginning of the game, it even took me about 10 minutes to figure out how to begin the first mission! 

[h1]Final Evidence is not consistent with Evidence Requirements[/h1]
At the beginning of each mission, you are given specific key evidence to look out for while analyzing individuals. Several times, the evidence the game wanted me to find were inconsistent with the requirements it gave me. This meant I often “missed” evidence which was never actually listed as a requirement.

[h1]Inconsistent Results after Missions[/h1]
As part of the story, you need to build up your agency's trust in you by successfully analyzing, identifying key elements a suspect might exhibit, and eventually classifying the subject as safe or a threat. These trust points given, however, were often inconsistent. Successfully classify and identify all pieces of evidence in a mission? Have 15 trust points! Missed one piece of evidence? There goes 30 points!

[h1]Inconsistent Dialogue[/h1]
Have a bad day and lose a lot of trust points? Doesn't matter, your boss will let you know what a great job you did today!

[h1]Bugs and Glitches[/h1]
While many people (such as myself) disregard the bug warnings in games and play them anyway only to still have a positive experience, let me tell you that it is not the case with this game. Throughout playing, I experienced numerous bugs, some of which were game breaking or needed a restart. For example, after losing in the prologue (why is that even possible?) and making a new profile the game glitched out and showed two different points in the story, progressing through them simultaneously, requiring a full restart of the game and clearing out the old profile and creating a new profile. Notifications on your in-game phone often appear and disappear in under a second, not giving you enough time to read what it says. You can’t even change the wallpaper.

[h1]In Conclusion[/h1]
In its current state, I cannot recommend Need to Know. The game has vital problems that it needs to solve, problems so important that it makes you wonder if Monomyth Games even play-tested all the features in-game before the final release, in despite of several beta versions being released to Kickstarter backers in the previous months. The game feels like a rushed beta version, even though the game was delayed by a month. Should Monomyth Games fix these key issues, I would gladly re-purchase the game for another shot at Need to Know.
developer_response:
Hi, we’re glad you followed Need to Know so closely, and are sorry that it disappointed you upon release. We appreciated your thorough, clear review, and have since worked hard to address many of the issues you raised.

[h1]Lack of Tutorial[/h1]
Tutorials are now in place for key points in the game, particularly in the opening sequences. Gameplay is now also more clearly directed, and will continue to improve.

[h1]User Interface[/h1]
Our UI scaling now sets all windows much smaller as a default, and allows you to adjust the size with a slider to fit your preferences, which helps to minimize visual clutter. We can see how the interface was initially confusing, but with the new tutorials and more visual guidance, you should find that this issue has been heavily remedied.

[h1]Final Evidence is not consistent with Evidence Requirements[/h1]
Thanks to our helpful, enthusiastic community, we’ve corrected the vast majority of these inconsistencies. Although some may still be lurking around, they should now be negligible, and we’re working to root them out as soon as they’re reported. 

[h1]Inconsistent Results after Missions[/h1]
Although the Department of Liberty is an unforgiving organization that does not tolerate mistakes, we understand that the point deductions may have been harsh (particularly when coupled with unclear gameplay). We’ve rebalanced the Compliance system, so that you won’t be punished as heavily for errors. 

[h1]Inconsistent Dialogue[/h1]
We agree that this issue would have been immersion-breaking! Since release, we’ve expanded dialogue branches in most post-mission conversations so that NPCs now react more accurately to your performance. Your boss will no longer pat you on the back for a terrible work performance. 

[h1]Bugs and Glitches[/h1]
We have fixed major, game-breaking bugs and addressed a host of minor issues that made the experience far more burdensome than it needed to be. The glitches you experienced should now be long-gone, and you can no longer be booted from the Department after the opening interview sequence. Though it was possible to re-load the game at this point, this was not clear enough, resulting in some players replaying the entire intro, which would have been irritating.
Also, you can change your phone wallpaper, and we’ll soon be adding a much larger range!

You and other reviewers are right in pointing out the game’s flaws on release, and we appreciate that you managed to be constructively critical without any malice. Since launch though, we’ve worked very hard to correct these problems, and in the future, will continue to make the game richer and more complex. For example, we’re currently implementing financial pressures, and more choice-based outcomes for home missions.

If you do get a chance to try the game again, and you encounter any issues you'd like to let us know about, you can head over to the Steam discussions or our Trello board [url=https://trello.com/b/ABG1gSZb/need-to-know-bugs-feature-requests]here[/url], and we'll fix it as soon as we can!

We really hope you give Need to Know another shot, and that your second experience is much more closely aligned with your expectations. Thanks for your time!

author: {'steamid': '76561198038495684', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 752, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 532, 'last_played': 1535580419}
review:
I backed this on Kickstarter, I played the demo and the Kickstarter beta. Both of which were nice examples of the software that worked fairly nice but were obviously just beta software.

The main issue with this game as it stands is it is still that - beta. It's as if absolutely no QA was done to the game before release. No matter how much I dislike "early access" or beta title on Steam, I find it surprising Monomyth didn't go this route or at least run a short closed beta to get input from users on functionality and bugs.

As it stands the current version is pretty much just the beta with more content and more bugs. The game is riddled with tiny bugs and typos that would have been found by a normal group of testers. It's also riddled with usability issues.

[list]
[*] The lack of a clear tutorial is confusing - and piecing together how you're supposed to go about things using peepr is a PITA.
[*] The UI is stale and unintuitive. Very few of the buttons in the UI you need to press are actually animated - with no indication you've moused over them or that they are a button.
[*] Another UI issue - no skip buttons? No way to skip over cutscenes.
[*] Lack of customization - why even offer a screen to customize your character when you've got 3 combinations?
[/list]

Overall with those usability issues and the current bugs, I'm going to have to say I can't recommend this. Follow the project, see if they fix things up in a timely manner - but if you didn't already buy it years ago - you're probably better off waiting to see if you can get a better experience.

review:
I feel the game is quite a bit of fun but some of the negative reviews are correct in pointing out that instructions are sometimes less than clear.

On your first day of "work" (after getting hired) the mission briefing doesn't really explain specifically what you need to do.  I played the alpha and beta of this game and I can tell you that they actually did a better job of explaining this, not sure why they altered it.  Also they changed the assignment "rules" screen which used to be divided between suspicious people and suspicious data, now it just lists everything in a single list.  I personally liked it the old way but that may just be a subjective thing.

For those who are confused here are a few pointers to get you started:

1. On each suspects profile open their evidence which will be their web browsing history and/or their phone records.

2. If you find one of the names or websites in the assignment rules in those sections you need to:
   a) right click and select blacksheep tool
   b) select the relevant data (name or website)
   c) select the rule it relates to in the rules page
   d) mark the suspect as a "Threat" using the lightning (powers) button

3. If you find no evidence matching the rules, just click the powers button and select "Safe".

I don't know why the devs thought it would be a good idea to leave the above (or similar) instructions out of their game as it is bound to put people off, so yeah, I can understand some of the negatives so far.  But personally, I'm marking this as "recommended" because I'm enjoying it and I can say from playing the beta that the story gets more interesting as you get further into it.

Having said that, I really do hope the devs sort out this point of making things clearer to first time users.

review:
Ok, so I've been waiting for this game for so long. First, I was extremely hyped up. After playing demo for some time my enthusiasm went down a bit, mainly because of lack of real, engaging gameplay, very clunky interface and lack of clarity in every screen in the game. Still, game looked beautiful with it's cartoon style and many cool symbols, graphics, and so. And now finally it's out. While I still think that this kind of a game has great potential (UPLINK, anyone?), unfortunately Need to Know is very hard to enjoy, despite it's visual charm. 

First, there are so many small, but annoying things, like unresponsivness or lack of skip button during certain screens. There's a lot of it in this game, and I wonder why those things weren't eliminated during long developement time. 

Second, despite the fact that the game looks great, the whole interface is a confusing mess. It is so hard to figure out what you are supposed to do, there are so many buttons and aditional cards around and no tutorial. It is so confusing, since so much is just randomly generated and serves just as an extra, cause...

Third. The gameplay. It is actually a memory clicking game (Think of it as a very flawed "Papers Please"). Granted, I played for an hour or two, but it gets repetitive already, and it doesn't feel real at all. There is no real suspense, just randomly generated trivia facts and phrases you have to find as fast as you can. It's no fun, at least for me. No excitement, no immersion. 

I'm sure the game gets more complex after a while: there is shop app in your phone and some stuff to buy, there are new "powers" that you unlock while advancing in the ranks of the agency, but everything feels undeveloped, almost like a free mobile game. And that's a shame, cause the visual style is (again) amazing, and the story is at least ok. So, maybe in Need To Know 2? 

Pros:
- Cool visual style
- Exciting topic 
- Modernately interesting story 

Cons:
- TERRIBLE interface
- Repetitive and almost non-existent gameplay
- Really annoying mechanics choices (No skip button? C'mon...)

Eventually, it's a no, unless you are willing to play repetitive memo / visual novel game and are patient enough to constantly fight with the interface.
